awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Enabling Multimodal Sensing, Real-time Onboard Detection and Adaptive Control for Fully Autonomous Unmanned Aerial Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to investigate a low-cost and energy-efficient hardware and software system to close the loop between processing of sensor data, semantically high-level detection and trajectory generation in real-time. To safely integrate Unmanned Aerial Vehicles into national airspace, there is an urgent need to develop onboard sense-and-avoid capability. While deep neural networks (DNNs) have significantly improved the accuracy of object detection and decision making, they have prohibitively high complexity to be implemented on small UAVs. Moreover, existing UAV flight control approaches ignore the nonlinearities of UAVs and do not provide trajectory assurance. 

The research thrusts of this project are: (i) FPGA implementation of DNNs: both fully connected and convolutional layers of deep (convolutional) neural networks will be trained using (block-)circulant matrix and implemented using custom designed universal Fast Fourier Transform kernels on FPGA. This research thrust will enable efficient implementation of DNNs, reducing memory and computation complexity from O(N2) to O(N) and O(NlogN), respectively; (ii) autonomous detection and perception for onboard sense-and-avoid: existing regional detection neural networks will be extended to work with images taken from different angles, and multi-modal sensor inputs; (iii) real-time waypoint and trajectory generation - an integrated trajectory generation and feedback control scheme for steering under-actuated vehicles through desired waypoints in 3D space will be developed. For efficient implementation and hardware reuse, both detection and control problems will be formulated and solved using DNNs with (block-)circulant weight matrix. Deep reinforcement learning models will be investigated for waypoint generation and to assign artificial potential around the obstacles to guarantee a safe distance. The fundamental research results will enable onboard computing, real-time detection and control, which are cornerstones of autonomous and next-generation UAVs.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to achieve true onboard autonomy in real time for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) without remote control or external navigation aids. Techniques for very low-power and low-cost machine intelligence have been developed to achieve multi-modal sensing, detection, and onboard adaptive control. The detection, optimization, trajectory planning and control problems in an autonomous UAV have been formulated and solved using deep neural networks (DNN) and deep reinforcement learning (DRL). A capsule network has been developed for 3D object classification. It can better capture the parts-relationship and yields more accurate classification with less training data. A two-level optimization framework has been developed for UAV trajectory optimization using a mixture of expert knowledge and machine learning. The lower-level performs nonlinear optimal trajectory planning to search for the most energy efficient connection between two waypoints, while the upper-level performs waypoints generation using a policy learned by reinforcement learning. A demo system has been developed on a quadrotor UAV platform that was built from commercial off-the-shelf components, including PX4 autopilot, Intel T265 vision sensor, and Jetson Xavier NX based companion processor. Based on the sensor information, the waypoints, trajectory and velocity were calculated onboard using the two-level optimization framework in real-time and sent to the PX4 autopilot for flight control. 

In addition, an Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM)-based weight pruning techniques have been developed, which rapidly compress the size of the DNNs, and thus significantly reduce the computing and storage complexity. The ADMM can be understood as a smart regularization technique with regularization target dynamically updated in each iteration, thereby resulting in higher performance in model compression than prior work. The optimized weight pruning method has been applied to compress the 3D object classifier and Deep Q-learning network, to keep the model compact enough for mobile deployment. The pruning of the DQN model reduces more than 40% of the storage requirement and improves the inference speed by more than 30%. Since the pruning only relies on the replay buffer instead of the interaction with the environment, it also reduces the training time of reinforcement learning. Applying the ADMM pruning with a set of thorough architecture-aware compiler/code generation-based optimizations, i.e., filter kernel reordering, compressed weight storage, register load redundancy elimination, and parameter auto-tuning, the developed approach can outperform three state-of-the-art end-to-end DNN frameworks, TensorFlow Lite, TVM, and Alibaba Mobile Neural Network with speedup up to 44.5×, 11.4×, and 7.1×.

 


Last Modified: 01/22/2022
Modified by: Qinru Qiu
